Gorbačov opozarja na ogromno nevarnost, ki grozi svetu
04 Nov 2019, 14:52 by STA

Zadnji sovjetski voditelj Mihail Gorbačov opozarja, da svetu zaradi napetosti med Rusijo in Zahodom ter jedrskega orožja, ki ga imata, grozi "ogromna nevarnost". V danes objavljenem pogovoru za britanski BBC je vse države pozval k uničenju jedrskega orožja.



Zadnji sovjetski voditelj Mihail Gorbačov opozarja, da svetu zaradi napetosti med Rusijo in Zahodom ter jedrskega orožja, ki ga imata, grozi "ogromna nevarnost".  Foto: Vir: Wikipedia

LONDON > "Dokler bo obstajalo orožje za množično uničevanje, še posebej jedrsko, obstaja ogromna nevarnost," je dejal Gorbačov, ki je nekdanjo Sovjetsko zvezo vodil od leta 1985 do njenega razpada leta 1991.
"Vsi narodi morajo jasno povedati, da je treba jedrsko orožje uničiti", saj bomo na ta način "rešili sebe in planet", je poudaril 88-letni nekdanji voditelj.
Čeprav mnogi analitiki menijo, da se je hladna vojna med Moskvo in Zahodom končala z razpadom Sovjetske zveze, je Gorbačov mnenja, da med stranema še vedno obstaja vzdušje vojne, čeprav nekoliko manj hladno.
"Poglejte, kaj se dogaja. Na različnih območjih so spori, prihaja do streljanja. Letala in ladje pošiljajo sem in tja ter vsepovsod. To niso razmere, ki si jih želimo," je še dejal Gorbačov, ki je leta 1990 prejel Nobelovo nagrado za mir za vodilno vlogo v mirovnem procesu, ki je vodil do padca Berlinskega zidu in "hladno vojno privedel do mirnega konca".
Prejel jo je za sklenitev zgodovinske pogodbe o prepovedi jedrskih raket srednjega dosega (INF) z ameriškim predsednikom Ronaldom Reaganom leta 1987. S pogodbo sta se obe strani zavezali k uničenju vseh jedrskih in konvencionalnih raket kratkega in srednjega dosega, torej raket z dosegom med 500 in 5500 kilometrov. Enako je veljalo za lanserje teh raket. Z njo sta želela preprečiti obstoj raket, ki bi evropska ali ruska mesta dosegle z malo ali nič opozorilnega časa.
Iz pogodbe je letos izstopil ameriški predsednik Donald Trump, nato pa še Moskva. Strani se medsebojno obtožujeta kršenja pogodbe.

Gorbachev points to the enormous danger that threatens the world
04 Nov 2019, 14:52 by STA

The last Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, warns that the world is threatened by "enormous danger" because of tensions between Russia and the West and the nuclear weapons they have. In an interview with the BBC today, he called on all countries to destroy nuclear weapons.



The last Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, warns that the world is threatened by "enormous danger" because of tensions between Russia and the West and the nuclear weapons they have. Photo: Source: Wikipedia

LONDON> "As long as there are weapons of mass destruction, especially nuclear, there is enormous danger," said Gorbachev, who led the former Soviet Union from 1985 until its dissolution in 1991.
"All nations must make it clear that nuclear weapons must be destroyed," as we will "save ourselves and the planet in this way," the 88-year-old former leader stressed.
Although many analysts believe the Cold War between Moscow and the West ended with the collapse of the Soviet Union, Gorbachev believes that there is still an atmosphere of war between the parties, albeit slightly less cold.
"Look at what's going on. There are conflicts in different areas, there is shooting. Planes and ships are sending here and there and everywhere. These are not the conditions we want," said Gorbachev, who won the 1990 Nobel Prize for peace for a leading role in the peace process leading to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the "Cold War" leading to a peaceful end.
He received it to conclude a historic mid-range nuclear missile (INF) treaty with US President Ronald Reagan in 1987. The treaty pledged both parties to destroy all nuclear and conventional short- and medium-range missiles, i.e., missiles with a range between 500 and 5500 kilometers. The same was true of the launchers of these rockets. They wanted to prevent missiles from reaching European or Russian cities with little or no warning time.
This year, US President Donald Trump, then Moscow, stepped down. The parties accuse each other of breach of contract.
